This course did an excellent job of covering a wide-variety of topics in detail, as well as considering the possibilities involved in future innovation.

The first few lectures on the general history and background for what the seminar covered, however, were not as engaging as later lectures.

The course is a decent gut science course for those looking to gain basic knowledge of modern scientific advancements. It covers a variety of topics, has a relaxed workload, and features many diverse speakers and trips around Yale campus. The environment it fosters is non-threatening and very manageable, and the relatively small class size makes it feel like a community. The student-researched presentations were the most personally rewarding, and where I was able to learn the most.

Although the topics themselves are interesting and the class relaxed, I found the curriculum and teaching disappointing. First and foremost, despite being a first-year seminar, the course is overtly a lecture class. Students rarely participated, and the lecture itself lacked direction, glossed over many complex concepts and facts, and failed to engage with the interests of the students. The fact that several students in such a small "seminar" could be found sleeping each class speaks to this. I felt the curriculum itself was also poorly paced and structured; the course seemed much like a rehash of high school science and history that last-minute remembered to include some sparse commentary on public policy and throw in some articles that were quickly discussed and then forgotten.

My opinion is that low-expectation classes like these are not necessarily bad. It is okay to have a course that is relaxed and features a low work load. But the information offered in class should at the very least be effective. If not to simply add more diverse and engaging discussion in which the questions asked of students are not simply rhetorical, yes-no, or based on rote memorization, the lecture material itself might benefit from being taught in a more "top-down" approach starting with relevant tech-based policy issues that capture student interest, and then explaining them using concrete and well-explained scientific concepts (eg. starting with the role of Facebook/social media in the 2016 election, and then analyzing how neural nets, algorithms, computing, bots, Moore's Law, quantum computing, etc. do or will play a role in politics.) The course could also focus on preparing students specifically for the guest lectures and trips so that they can be more readily applicable and enlightening, rather than just an interesting side diversion vaguely connected to the material. The teacher should be more active in interacting with the students and their interests, as well as current events, and give deeper explanations of the science.
